items.description: Loughborough urban watercourses and local tributaries to the River Soar
items.message:
Small, flashier rivers and streams are beginning to respond to heavy rainfall as a result of localised thunderstorms passing through the area.  
Areas most at risk are low lying agricultural land, roads and footpaths close to small rivers and streams.  Water levels could rise rapidly and potentially generate deep, fast flows.   
We expect river levels to remain high until 21:00 on 20/06/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid contact with flood water and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 20:00 this evening, 20/06/23, or as the situation changes."

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have risen rapidly on the River Cole and Dorcan Brook as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying roads, footpaths and land is expected this morning 20/06/23, especially in the Swindon area. 
Further rainfall is forecast this morning before clearing this afternoon. We expect river levels to rise this morning before starting to drop. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.
 
This message will be updated.

River levels are rising on the Middlesbrough Becks due to heavy rainfall. Flooding is possible at riverside footpaths and low-lying land and roads from now until later this afternoon Tuesday, 20/06/2023.
Further heavy rainfall is forecast this afternoon. The forecast is dry for this evening.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 06:00 PM on 20/06/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Scrase Bridge and West Common Streams

floodArea.riverOrSea: Scrase Bridge Stream, West Common Stream

items.message: The intense showers of early Tuesday morning (20/06/2023) have now moved away. River levels on the Scrasebridge and West Common Streams have fallen significantly from their peak, are now near normal, and are still falling. The next five days are currently forecast to remain predominantly dry. We do not currently expect further periods of flood risk this week. However, further isolated showers are possible Wednesday and Thursday (22/06/2023). We will continue to monitor the river levels and rainfall forecast, and proactively clear and operate our structures. Please continue to monitor the weather forecast for updates on the potential showers over the coming days, and take precautions with flood resistance and resilience measures if appropriate. We will re-issue this Flood Alert, or a Flood Warning if the risk of flooding becomes possible or expected again.

floodArea.county: Barnet, Enfield, Essex, Greater London, Haringey, Hertfordshire, Redbridge, Waltham Forest
floodArea.riverOrSea: Ching Brook, Cobbins Brook, Nazeing Brook, Pymmes Brook, Salmons Brook, Turkey Brook, Small River Lee, Rags Brook, Trinity Marsh Ditch

items.message:
Heavy rain this morning on Tuesday 20 June caused river levels on the tributaries of the River Lee to rise.

River levels have now dropped but due to the potential for thunderstorms to develop this afternoon and into this evening a risk of flooding remains in areas including Waltham Forest, Waltham Abbey, Waltham Cross, Barnet, Nazeing, Enfield, Chingford, Edmonton, Cheshunt and Tottenham. 
   
Flooding from surface water, where water gathers and flows off road surfaces, could also occur.  

The risk of thunderstorms remains until around 8pm before we move into a largely dry night.

No flooding to properties is currently expected. 

Flood waters may be polluted, do not enter flood waters. Wash your hands thoroughly if you’ve been in contact with it.

We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff on standby to attend to any blockages in the river. 

This message will be updated by 9pm this evening or as the situation changes.
